page.title: 03Landscape & buildings
page.content: The villages of Coniston and Swine in Holderness lie on the eastern edge of the Hull valley. The landscape is low lying with the large open fields typical of the plain of Holderness with its thick strata of boulder clay overlaying the chalk base. The only buildings of any note in Coniston are the modern village hall and the local inn, 'The Blacksmiths' Arms'. However, Swine boasts a fine church, parts of which date from 1150 when a priory church of Cistercian nuns was established on the site. Apart from the two villages, the only other buildings in this typically rural backwater are nine residential units and twelve farms scattered over the countryside.
